verses.text: Children, listen to your father’s instruction, and act so that you may be safe.
verses.comment: This verse reflects the importance of receiving wisdom from one’s parents, echoing the commandment to honor father and mother (Ex. 20:12). Obedience brings spiritual and practical safety.

verses.text: For the Lord has given the father honor over the children, and has confirmed the mother’s authority over her sons.
verses.comment: Parental authority is divinely instituted. Recognizing and submitting to this order aligns one with God’s will, mirroring obedience to God Himself.

verses.text: Whoever honors his father makes atonement for sins,
verses.comment: Honoring one’s father is associated here with the forgiveness of sins—prefiguring the connection between acts of love and reconciliation with God (Matt. 6:14–15).

verses.text: and whoever glorifies his mother is like one who lays up treasure.
verses.comment: Loving and respecting one’s mother is likened to storing up heavenly treasure (Matt. 6:20). Spiritual riches are acquired through concrete acts of devotion in the family.

verses.text: Whoever honors his father will be gladdened by children, and when he prays he will be heard.
verses.comment: Obedience not only brings familial blessings, but also a more receptive prayer life—God listens to the righteous and just (Ps. 145:19).

verses.text: Whoever glorifies his father will have a long life, and whoever obeys the Lord will comfort his mother.
verses.comment: Long life as a reward echoes the promise of the Law, linking natural obedience to supernatural reward (Eph. 6:2–3).

verses.text: He who fears the Lord honors his parents;
verses.comment: True reverence for God manifests in respectful relationships within the home.

verses.text: he serves them as masters, and gives his life for them by his deeds and words.
verses.comment: Obedience to parents is not mere sentiment but active service—an anticipation of Christ’s call to lay down one’s life for others (cf. John 15:13).

verses.text: Honor your father with all your heart, and do not forget the struggles of your mother.
verses.comment: The duty to remember a mother's sacrifices reinforces the biblical theme of gratitude.

verses.text: Remember that they gave you birth; how can you repay them for what they have done for you?
verses.comment: The impossibility of fully repaying our parents mirrors our relationship with God’s grace (cf. Ps. 71:6).

verses.text: A father’s blessing strengthens his children’s house, but a mother’s curse uproots its foundations.
verses.comment: Parental blessings and curses have spiritual weight; blessings build up, curses destroy (see Prov. 27:14).

verses.text: Do not boast in dishonor over your father’s disgrace, for it is no glory to you.
verses.comment: Dishonoring parents brings shame rather than glory, violating biblical values on family respect.

verses.text: A father’s shame is no glory for a child, and it is a disgrace for any child to lack respect.
verses.comment: Disrespect toward parents is called out as disgraceful—a theme spanning both Testaments.

verses.text: My child, assist your father in his old age, and do not grieve him as long as he lives.
verses.comment: Care for aging parents is a lasting obligation, anticipating New Testament themes of care (see 1 Tim. 5:4).

verses.text: And if his mind fails you, be patient and do not despise him while you are in your strength.
verses.comment: Patience and mercy are key, even when the parent’s faculties decline—showing the heart of true piety.

verses.text: For kindness to a father will not be forgotten, and it will stand in your favor and wipe out your sins.
verses.comment: Almsgiving and good works, such as mercy to parents, are said here to cover sins—found in Old and New Testament teachings (James 5:20).

verses.text: On the day of your affliction it will be remembered, and your sins will melt away like frost in the warmth.
verses.comment: Divine mercy is connected to our own merciful actions. The clear connection between forgiveness and works anticipates Christ’s teaching (Luke 6:38).

verses.text: Whoever abandons his father is like a blasphemer, and whoever provokes his mother is cursed by the Lord.
verses.comment: Strong language is used—the abandonment of parents is likened to blasphemy. Divine curses are tied to breaking family bonds.

verses.text: My child, act with humility in all you do, and you will be loved more than a giver of gifts.
verses.comment: Humility is more highly esteemed than material generosity. Jesus likewise teaches the blessedness of the humble (Matt. 5:5).

verses.text: The greater you become, the more you should humble yourself, and you will find favor before the Lord.
verses.comment: Spiritual greatness is seen in humility, echoing James 4:6—God opposes the proud but gives grace to the humble.

verses.text: For the Lord is high and glorious, but he is pleased with the humble.
verses.comment: The spiritual value of humility is consistent with later apostolic teaching (1 Pet. 5:5; Ps. 138:6).

verses.text: Do not seek what is too difficult for you, nor investigate what is beyond your strength.
verses.comment: Trusting God’s mysteries is a virtue; curiosity has limits for the faithful.

verses.text: Contemplate what is commanded to you, for things hidden are not your concern.
verses.comment: Faithfulness to known truths precedes understanding what is concealed. Obedience is key.

verses.text: Do not meddle in things beyond you, for more is shown to you than your understanding can grasp.
verses.comment: Humility before mystery foreshadows New Testament themes of childlike trust (cf. Matt. 18:3).

verses.text: For many have been misled by their own speculation, and an evil mind has led them astray.
verses.comment: Self-reliance apart from divine wisdom leads to error. This anticipates warnings against false doctrine.

verses.text: A stubborn heart ends badly, and those who love danger will perish because of it.
verses.comment: Stubbornness and recklessness are consistently exposed as leading to ruin in biblical wisdom.

verses.text: A stubborn heart will be loaded with troubles, and the sinner increases sin upon sin.
verses.comment: Persistence in sin compounds spiritual misery.

verses.text: The misfortune of the proud has no remedy, for evil has taken root in them.
verses.comment: Pride leads to destruction, as echoed in broader biblical tradition.

verses.text: The heart of the intelligent ponders a proverb, and an attentive ear is the desire of the wise.
verses.comment: Active contemplation and listening are integral to wisdom.

verses.text: Water extinguishes a blazing fire, and almsgiving atones for sins.
verses.comment: Good works, especially almsgiving, are said to spiritually cleanse—this anticipates the New Testament’s affirmation that charity covers sins.

verses.text: He who returns a kindness remembers the future; at the time of his fall, he will find support.
verses.comment: The principle of spiritual reciprocity (see Luke 6:38) is illustrated: mercy shown will be mercy received. This models the biblical understanding of grace and reward.
